intro: Dipsacus kangdingensis, commonly known as the Kangding teasel, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western China. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its spiny, leaf-like bracts that surround its flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its flowers are usually yellow or brown, and it produces small, spherical fruits that disperse seeds by wind. Dipsacus kangdingensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological significance in its native habitat.
